title: Never Tell Me The Odds (Ratio)
summary:
Key ideas
- Odds ratios can be misleading in terms of the actual effect size of a treatment or intervention.
- Chen's How Big is a Big Odds Ratio? Interpreting the Magnitudes of Odds Ratios in Epidemiological Studies, offers a way to convert odds ratios into effect sizes.
- A quick heuristic for this conversion is to ignore prevalence and use [ln(odds ratio)]/1.81.

Key learnings
- Odds ratios should not be relied upon to gauge the magnitude of an effect.
- Effect sizes are a better metric for comparing different studies or treatments.
- A heuristic formula can be used to convert odds ratios into effect sizes.

Key questions
- What other measures can be used to accurately gauge the size of an effect?
- Why is there still a reliance on odds ratios in reporting study results?
- How can researchers ensure that their results accurately quantify the effects of a treatment or intervention?
